subHeader: To know how FusionTime works, you need to understand the different components and concepts of a chart

content.header: In the sections below, you can find interactive annotated images describing various components and concepts of charts

annotations.annotationDesc: Canvas area refers to the area in which the chart data is plotted, excluding the area where titles, legends, and axis names are rendered.
Data plot refers to the columns of the column chart, lines in a line chart, pie/doughnut slices in a pie/doughnut chart.

annotationLinks.linkDesc: You can customize the way your data plot looks using colors, gradients and hover effects using available attributes, learn more about their usage

annotations.annotationDesc: Time Axis refers to a line on a chart that runs horizontally (left to right).
Time markers are the names of the data points that are displayed on the time axis of a chart. Learn more about them

annotationLinks.linkDesc: You can customize the way time markers look. Learn more about their usage

annotations.annotationDesc: Y-Axis refers to a line on a chart that runs vertically (up-down) through zero. Learn more about it

annotationLinks.linkDesc: You can customize the way the Y-axis looks. Learn more about it

annotations.annotationDesc: It refers to the title of the y-axis. Learn more about it
It refers to the selector for standard time periods. Learn more about it
It refers to the selector for custom time periods. Learn more about it
It lets you narrow the focus to a specific time period without losing context of the entire data. Learn more about it

A legend is a chart element used to display the series name for each dataset, in case of multi-series or combination charts. Legends are used to correlate a data plot to its series name using its color.

annotationLinks.linkDesc: You can choose to show/hide the legend. Learn how to do it
You can choose to hide one or more legend items when the chart is initially rendered. Learn how to do it

annotations.annotationDesc: A tooltip is displayed when the mouse cursor hovers over a particular data point. It provides context-sensitive information about the data point. Learn more about it
